question: Question_02_(c)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problem.} Justify your answers and \textbf{show
all your work.} Simplification of answers is not required.

Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region bounded by
the curves $y=5$ and $y=x+(4/x)$ about the line $x=-1$.
sols:
The first step to solve this problem is to understand what volume we are
trying to compute.

The question states that there is a region bounded by the curves
\emph{y}=5 and \emph{y}=\emph{x}+4/\emph{x}. For large values of
\emph{x} the second curve looks like the line \emph{y}=\emph{x}, but
there is also a vertical asymptote at \emph{x}=0. So it seems that it
will indeed cross the horizontal line \emph{y}=5 twice (as it dips down
before going back up). We can compute where the intersections are by
solving:

\[x+\frac{4}{x} = 5\] which is equivalent to

\[\displaystyle
0 = x^2-5x+4 = (x-1)(x-4)\] and has solutions \emph{x}=1 and \emph{x}=4.
Then we want to know how far down the curve goes, so we look for its
local minimum. We compute its derivative:

\[\frac{d}{dx}\left(x+\frac{4}{x}\right) = 1 - \frac{4}{x^2}\] and hence
see that it has two critical points, one at \emph{x}=-2 and one at
\emph{x}=2. We are only interested in the local minimum which is at
\emph{x}=2. This should be enough details to have you be able to obtain
the equivalent of the following picture:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2008_Question_2_(c)_picture_1.png}
\caption{Math Exam Resources Courses MATH101 April 2008 Question 2 (c) picture 1.gif}
\end{figure}

This in particular shows that \emph{y}=5 is bigger than
\emph{y}=\emph{x}+4/\emph{x}.

Now, consider a point \emph{x} between 1 and 4. The distance from
\emph{x} to \emph{x}=-1 is the radius of the cylindrical shell and is
\emph{r}=\emph{x}+1. The height of the function at this point is the
difference of the top function \emph{y}=5 to the bottom function
\emph{y}=\emph{x}+4/\emph{x} which is 5-\emph{x}-4/\emph{x}. When we
rotate, we travel a distance of $2\pi r$ (the circumference) and we are
multiplying by $h\Delta x$. Thus, we have

\begin{align*}
V &= \int_{1}^{4}2\pi(x+1)(5-x-4/x)\,dx \\
&= 2\pi\int_{1}^{4}(5x-x^{2}-4 + 5-x-4/x)\,dx \\
&= 2\pi\int_{1}^{4}(-x^{2}+4x +1-4/x)\,dx \\
&= 2\pi(-x^{3}/3 + 2x^{2} + x - 4\ln|x|)\bigg|_{1}^{4} \\
&= 2\pi((-(4)^{3}/3 + 2(4)^{2} + 4 - 4\ln|4|) - (-(1)^{3}/3 + 2(1)^{2} + 1 - 4\ln|1|))\\
&= 2\pi((-64/3 + 32 + 4 - 4\ln|4|) - (-1/3 + 2 + 1 -0))\\
&= 2\pi(12 -4\ln|4|)\\
&= 2\pi(12 -8\ln(2))\\
&= 8\pi(3 -2\ln(2)) \\
&= 24\pi - 16\pi \ln(2)
\end{align*}

Where each of the last four answers are equivalent and would be accepted
as a final answer.

The first step to solve this problem is to understand what volume we are
trying to compute.

The question states that there is a region delimited by the curves
\emph{y}=5 and \emph{y}=\emph{x}+4/\emph{x}. The second curve looks like
the line \emph{y}=\emph{x} except that there is a vertical asymptote at
\emph{x}=0. So it seems that it will indeed cross the horizontal line
\emph{y}=5 twice (as it dips down before going back up). We can compute
where the intersections are by solving:

\[x+\frac{4}{x} = 5\] which is equivalent to

\[\displaystyle
x^2-5x+4=0\] and has solutions \emph{x}=1 and \emph{x}=4. Then we want
to know how far down the curve goes, so we look for its local minimum.
We compute its derivative:

\[\frac{d}{dx}\left(x+\frac{4}{x}\right) = 1 - \frac{4}{x^2}\] and hence
see that it has two critical points, one at \emph{x}=-2 and one at
\emph{x}=2. We are only interested in the local minimum which is at
\emph{x}=2. This should be enough details to have you be able to obtain
the equivalent of the following picture:

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{Math_Exam_Resources_Courses_MATH101_April_2008_Question_2_(c)_picture_1.png}
\caption{Math Exam Resources Courses MATH101 April 2008 Question 2 (c) picture 1.gif}
\end{figure}

Now we want to rotate this region around the vertical axis \emph{x}=-1.
To do this, we will use the method know as
\href{http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disk_integration}{disk integration}.
The idea is fairly simple: imagine the solid viewed from the top
(looking down at the axis), if we slice it along that axis, we will see
a slice of a hollow cylinder. We will compute the area of that slice
(the difference of area between the outer disk and the inner disk) and
integrate.

The outer disc has a radius that starts at the point (2,4) and moves
right towards the point (4,5) following the curve
\emph{y}=\emph{x}+4/\emph{x}. The inner disc has a radius that starts at
the point (2,4) and moves left towards the point (1,5) following the
other side of the curve. We need to compute that radius (starting at
x=-1). For this, the first step is to express the curve in terms of
\emph{y} instead of \emph{x}:

\begin{align*}
y=x+\frac{4}{x} &\iff yx=x^2+4\\
& \iff x^2-yx+4=0\\
& \iff x=\frac{y \pm \sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}
\end{align*} If we look at this, it makes sense: This is only well
defined if \emph{y} is larger than 4 (see on the graph) and there are
two components: the one with the + for the right side and the one with
the - for the left side. Since the axis of rotation is at \emph{x}=-1,
we need to add 1 to each of the radius and obtain:

\begin{align*}
r_{outer}(y) &= 1+\frac{y + \sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}\\
r_{inner}(y) &= 1+\frac{y - \sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}
\end{align*} And so we can write the volume by integrating over all the
shells, which are obtained by taking the difference of the outer and
inner disk:

\[V = \int_4^5 \left( \pi \left( 1+\frac{y}{2} + \frac{\sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}\right)^2 - \pi \left( 1+\frac{y}{2} - \frac{\sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}\right)^2 \right) \,dy\]
(since the area of a disk of radius \emph{r} is $\pi$
r\textsuperscript{2}).

Now we can do some algebra to rewrite this integral into something
easier to handle. Notice the pattern here

\[\displaystyle
(A+B)^2 - (A-B)^2 = 4AB\] Hence we can rewrite this as

\begin{align*}
V &= \pi \int_4^5 4(1+\frac{y}{2})(\frac{\sqrt{y^2-16}}{2}) \,dy\\
&= \pi \int_4^5 (2+y)(\sqrt{y^2-16}) \,dy\\
\end{align*}

Now we need to compute that integral to obtain the desired volume.
Unfortunately, this won't be straightforward since (2+\emph{y}) isn't a
multiple of the derivative of what is in the square root. There are many
ways to compute this integral, here we will split it in 2 and deal with
each term.

\[V = \pi \int_4^5 2\sqrt{y^2-16} \,dy + \pi \int_4^5 y\sqrt{y^2-16} \,dy\]
Let us call the first integral V\textsubscript{1} and the second one
V\textsubscript{2}. The first one is the tougher one. Indeed:

\begin{align*}
V_2 &= \pi \int_4^5 y\sqrt{y^2-16} \,dy \\
&= \frac{\pi}{2} \int_4^5 2y\sqrt{y^2-16} \,dy \\
&= \frac{\pi}{2} \left[ \frac{2}{3}(y^2-16)^{3/2} \right]_4^5 \\
&= \frac{\pi}{2} \frac{2}{3} (25-16)^{3/2} \\
&= \frac{\pi}{3} \cdot 27 \\
&= 9\pi
\end{align*}

The first integral is actually quite complicated. At the same time it is
a classic. As of today (2012) you are not expected to be able to
integrate this by hand and/or know the formula from memory. For
completion sake, here is the formula:

\[\int \sqrt{x^2-a^2} \,dx = \frac{x}{2} \sqrt{x^2-a^2} - \frac{a^2}{2} \ln( x+ \sqrt{x^2-a^2}) + c\]
Which in this case gives us:

\begin{align*}
V_1 &= \pi \int_4^5 2\sqrt{y^2-16} \,dy \\
&= 2\pi \left[ \frac{y}{2} \sqrt{y^2-16} - 8 \ln( y+ \sqrt{y^2-16}) \right]_4^5 \\
&= 2\pi \left[ (\frac{5}{2} \sqrt{9} - 8 \ln( 5 + \sqrt{9} ) - (0 - 8 \ln( 4 + 0)) \right] \\
&= 2\pi (\frac{15}{2} - 8 \ln(8) + 8\ln(4) \\
&= \pi (15 - 48 \ln(2) + 32 \ln(2) ) \\
&= \pi (15 - 16\ln(2))
\end{align*}

Summing $\displaystyle V = V_{1} + V_{2}$ gives
$\displaystyle V = 24\pi - 16\pi\ln(2)$ which is the same as above.

... This is why using the correct method of solids of revolution is very
important.
